bibl.title: Letter from Mark Sullivan to Leonard Wood, July 1, 1925

div1.p: Sullivan wants Wood to make corrections to his manuscript on the history of the United States, in particular with any reference he makes to William Crawford Gorgas. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Mark Sullivan to Leonard Wood, July 1, 1925
div1.opener:
MARK SULLIVAN
91 Home Life Bldg.,
Washington, D.C.1
July 1, 1925.
My dear General Wood:
div1.p:
I am writing for Scribners a history of the United
States in our own times, that is, from 1900 to 1925.

In this history I want to lay a special emphasis
on the achievements of General Gorgas. I want to make the
point that some of the advances made in medicine and other forms
of science during these twenty-five years were really more fun-
damentally important than many of the things like politics which
enter more largely into most formal histories.

I want to tell the history of Gorgas accurately and
adequately. With this in mind I have completed the first draft.
I am taking the liberty of sending it to you to ask if you will
do me the favor to read it. If you are willing to read it at
all, please do so less in the spirit of approving it than in
the spirit of making it complete and accurate. What I want most
to find are the omissions or inaccuracies. I want to be sure I am
right both in the facts and also in the judgments, the point of
view and proportions.

I shall take it as a very great favor if you will read
the manuscript and dictate to your secretary whatever suggestions
occur to you. My recollection is that you were in Havana at the
time and that you would have the point of view of a person who ac-
tually witnessed the events.

If you can do this for me I shall be greatly indebted
to you.

I frequently run across friends of yours who greatly regret
the length of your absence from this country, notwithstanding their
appreciation of the importance of your work. Just the other evening
Mrs. Douglas Robinson was speaking of you.

I could write you a book about the present state of politics
in the United States and if you will tell me that you would like me to,
I shall do it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Sgd.) MARK SULLIVAN. General Leonard Wood,
Manila, P.I.
